maml:description.maml:para: Returns a value selected by the user from an Enumeration type.
When an enum type has been created to allow easy mapping of names to values, this function prompts the user to select one of the names, and returns the corresponding value.
The Enumeration type to use to build the selection list.
The Value returned if nothing is selected from the list (if not specified the function will return null).
The Enumeration type to used to build the selection list.
The Value returned if nothing is selected from the list (if not specified the function will return null).
Value of the selected item.

dev:remarks.maml:para: The user is offered choices "Allow" = 1 or "Block" = 0 , the two possible options in the fwAction (firewall action) enum, and the variable is set to 1 or 0, the associated values based on that choice.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns an object selected by the user from a table of numbered rows.

Takes a collection of objects and the list of properties to be displayed. This information is used to show a table with numbered rows. The user is prompted to make either a single or multiple choice, by row numbers and the selected objects are returned.
An array of objects which provide the data for the selection list. The data returned comes from this parameter as well. If a single item is provided, it is returned without showing the list. .
One or more property names used to format the selection list. .
Specifies that multiple items can be selected.
An array of objects which provide the data for the selection list. The data returned comes from this parameter as well. If a single item is provided, it is returned without showing the list.
One or more property names used to format the selection list.
Specifies that multiple items can be selected.
Returns a zero-based integer indicating the user's selection from a list.
A list of choices is displayed one after the other, and the users selection is returned as a zero-based integer. Can display a caption followed by a message before the choices.
An array of strings, each one is possible choice. The hot key in each choice must be prefixed with an & sign.
A caption to appear above the choices. .
A Message to appear between caption and the choices .
The item to be selected by default .
A hash table where each item is a possible choice. The name part is the text to display as the choice label, and the Value part is the Help text.
A caption to appear above the choices. .
A Message to appear between caption and the choices .
The item to be selected by default .
An array of strings, each one is possible choice. The hot key in each choice must be prefixed with an & sign.
A hash table where each item is a possible choice. The name part is the text to display as the choice label, and the Value part is the Help text.
A caption to appear above the choices .
A Message to appear between caption and the choices .
The item to be selected by default .
An integer indicating the selection.

command:example.maml:title: --------------- Example 1 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: select-item -Caption "Configuring RemoteDesktop" -Message "Do you want to: " -textChoices " &Disable Remote Desktop","&Enable Remote Desktop","&Cancel" -default 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: Configuring RemoteDesktop Do you want to: [D] Disable Remote Desktop [E] Enable Remote Desktop [C] Cancel [?] Help (default is "E"):.
The function accepts D, E ,or C as input and returns 0 for Disable, 1 for Enable and 2 for Cancel.

command:example.maml:title: --------------- Example 2 ------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Select-item @{"&Tea"="A drink made from leaves";"&Coffee"="A drink made from beans"}

dev:remarks.maml:para: Please make a selection Choices are presented below [T] Tea [C] Coffee [?] Help (default is "T"):.
Pressing ? will produce help as follows.
T - A drink made from leaves C - A drink made from beans.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: PromptForChoice Method of PSHostUserInterface on MSDN

maml:description.maml:para: Outputs objects in a tree format.

The function takes a collection of objects which must have: a property to display (label), a property identify the position in the tree (path) and a property which identifies a node's parent (parent).
The collection of items to output in the tree. May be passed via the pipe For backwards compatibility has an alias of "Items".
The first item in the branch of the tree to output.
The name of the property name which identifies a location in the tree. It does not need to be a fully qualified path, but must be unique.
The name of the property which holds the path of a node's parent.
The name of the property which holds the text to display.
The function is called recursively and this parameter specifies how far each branch of the tree is indented. It should not be passed from the command line.
The collection of items to output in the tree. May be passed via the pipe For backwards compatibility has an alias of "Items".
The first item in the branch of the tree to output.
The name of the property name which identifies a location in the tree. It does not need to be a fully qualified path, but must be unique.
The value of the path property which identifies a node's parent.
The name of the property which holds the text to display.
The function is called recursively and this parameter specifies how far each branch of the tree is indented. It should not be passed from the command line.

command:example.maml:title: ----- Example 1 -----
command:example.dev:code: dir -Recurse | Where-Object {$_.mode -like "D*"} | out-tree -start (get-item $pwd) -path pspath -parent psparentPath -label name

dev:remarks.maml:para: Outputs a tree of subfolders of the current folder; the starting item is the current folder, for each item in thee tree its path is stored in the PsPath property, and its parent is stored in the PsParentPath propery. The name property is output in the tree view.

maml:description.maml:para: Allows the user to select from objects in a tree format.

The function takes a collection of objects which must have: a property to display (label), a property identify the position in the tree (path) and a property which identifies a node's parent (parent). displays them tree format and prompts the user to choose one (or more than one if -Multiple is specified).
The collection of items to output in the tree. May be passed via the pipe For backwards compatibility has an alias of "Items".
The first item in the branch of the tree to output.
The name of the property name which identifies a location in the tree. It does not need to be a fully qualified path, but must be unique.
The name of the property which holds the path of a node's parent.
The name of the property which holds the text to display.
The function is called recursively and this parameter specifies how far each branch of the tree is indented. Should not be passed from the command line.
Determines whether a single or multiple selection is to made from the tree.
The collection of items to output in the tree. May be passed via the pipe For backwards compatibility has an alias of "Items".
The first item in the branch of the tree to output.
The name of the property name which identifies a location in the tree. It does not need to be a fully qualified path, but must be unique.
The value of the path property which identifies a node's parent.
The name of the property which holds the text to display.
The function is called recursively and this parameter specifies how far each branch of the tree is indented. Should not be passed from the command line.
Determines whether a single or multiple selection is to made from the tree.
Checks to see if the current session has administrator privileges.

Some tasks require administrator privileges, and on Windows Vista/Server 2008 and later this may require the user to choose "Run as administrator" when starting PowerShell The command returns a Boolean indicating the elevated status - true = elevated, false = not elevated.
$true if the session was started as administrator.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns true if the session was started as administrator, false otherwise.

maml:description.maml:para: Converts a logical disk index to a drive letter.
Converts a logical disk index to a drive letter.
An integer representing the index of the logical disk.
A WMI object representing a physical disk.
An integer representing the index of the logical disk.
A WMI object representing a physical disk.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns the drive letters of the partitions on the specified disk. For Example C:, D:.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns a CHAR indicating the first available drive letter.
Returns a CHAR indicating the first available drive letter.
First available drive letter.
Checks the status of background WMI jobs.
Some WMI functions create a background job, it may be necessary to wait for a job to complete, or simply to check its current state.
A WMI object representing a job. If a string is passed containing a WMI path it is converted to the WMI object automatically.
If not specified the Job WMI object is returned. If it is specified only the JobState Property is returned, saving the caller the step of getting the property.
If not specified the job will only be examined once. If specified it will be examined every 250 milliseconds as long as its state is "Running".
The Description to be displayed while waiting for the job to complete.
A WMI object representing a job. If a string is passed containing a WMI path it is converted to the WMI object automatically.
If not specified the Job WMI object is returned. If it is specified only the JobState Property is returned, saving the caller the step of getting the property.
If not specified the job will only be examined once. If specified it will be examined every 250 milliseconds as long as its state is "Running".
The Description to be displayed while waiting for the job to complete.
Checks the result returned by calling a WMI method.

When calling a WMI method the result will often by an object containing a return value, which indicates immediate success, the creation of a task to perform the job, or an error. Test-WMI result looks at this code and if necessary uses Test-WMIJob to see what the outcome of the job was.
The WMI Object returned by calling a method of another WMI object.
The text to be displayed on a progress indicator while waiting for the job to complete (if -wait is specified and a background job exists).
The text written to Verbose: if the method was successful.
The Text to be included with the error and written to error if the method fails.
If specified will wait for a background job to complete. If not specified a message will be written to Warning indicating the job is still running if it has not completed.
The WMI Object returned by calling a method of another WMI object.
The text to be displayed on a progress indicator while waiting for the job to complete (if -wait is specified and a background job exists).
The text written to Verbose: if the method was successful.
The Text to be included with the error and written to error if the method fails.
If specified will wait for a background job to complete. If not specified a message will be written to Warning indicating the job is still running if it has not completed.

maml:alert.maml:para: This command is expected to be used by other commands, not from the command line.
